headline: Ukraine weapons: What arms are the US, UK and other nations supplying?

annotations.paragraph: Concerns are rising that the US may no longer come to Europe's defence, which could force European countries - including the UK - to increase their military spending.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about potential shifts in defense responsibilities affecting military aid dynamics.

annotations.paragraph: Since the Russian full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, western nations have allocated more than $250bn (£205bn) of military, humanitarian and other financial aid to Ukraine.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives essential context about the scale of aid provided to Ukraine since the invasion.

annotations.paragraph: US President Donald Trump has said he wants Ukraine to guarantee the supply of more rare earth metals in exchange for further support.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a specific condition tied to future US support, relevant to the topic of military aid.

annotations.paragraph: The US has been the biggest source of military aid to Ukraine, including weapons, equipment and financial support.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a key fact about the US's role in supplying military aid to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Between the start of 2022 and the end of 2024, it gave $69bn (£54.6bn) in military aid, according to German think tank the Kiel Institute.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on the amount of military aid given by the US, which is directly relevant.

annotations.paragraph: Germany has given $13.6bn (£10.7bn), the UK $10.8bn (£8.5bn), Denmark $8.1bn (£6.4bn), and the Netherlands $6.3bn (£4.9bn).
annotations.reason: Provides specific financial contributions from various countries, relevant to the topic of international aid to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Your device may not support this visualisation
annotations.reason: This is a technical note unrelated to the article's main content.

annotations.paragraph: If all types of aid are included - military, humanitarian and other financial aid - data shows the US has spent about $120bn. That is 43% of total support to Ukraine since the start of 2022.
annotations.reason: Offers a comprehensive figure for US aid, providing context on the scale of support.

annotations.paragraph: European Union (EU) countries sent about 18.3% thought the bloc's institutions.
annotations.reason: Gives a percentage of EU contributions, relevant to understanding the distribution of aid.

annotations.paragraph: Some EU members, like Germany, have made additional contributions - as shown in the chart below.
annotations.reason: Mentions additional contributions by EU members, relevant to the topic of aid distribution.

annotations.paragraph: Given the current size of the US contribution, other countries would need to significantly increase support to make up any shortfall.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the scale of US contributions and the need for other countries to increase support.

annotations.paragraph: Last year, all European Nato members pledged to spend 2% of GDP on defence. Provisional figures, show the UK spent 2.33% (£64.6bn) in 2024, ranking it ninth out of all Nato members on this measure.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about the UK's defense spending in relation to NATO commitments.

annotations.paragraph: The Labour government has committed to increase this amount to 2.5%, although it hasn't set out when it expects to achieve this.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on future UK defense spending plans, relevant to the topic.

annotations.paragraph: Had the UK spent 2.5% of GDP on defence last year it would have cost an additional £4.6bn according to the House of Commons Library (although the Institute for Fiscal Studies puts the figure at £6bn).
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers hypothetical context on UK defense spending, which is relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Missiles and artillery
annotations.reason: This is a fragment and does not provide any substantial information.

annotations.paragraph: Both Ukrainian and Russian forces have used artillery and guided missiles extensively, to prevent enemy forces advancing and to attack supply depots and command centres.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the use of artillery and missiles by both sides.

annotations.paragraph: Ukraine has been using US-made ATACMS missiles which have a range of about 190 miles (300km).
annotations.reason: Introduces specific weaponry supplied to Ukraine by the US.

annotations.paragraph: In November, former President Biden  lifted the ban, allowing ATACMS to be fired into Russian territory.
annotations.reason: Provides relevant information on policy changes affecting weapon use.

annotations.paragraph: The UK and France have supplied Ukraine with Storm Shadow or Scalp missiles, which have a maximum range of around 155 miles (250km), and which Ukraine has reportedly fired into Russian territory.
annotations.reason: Details specific weapons supplied by the UK and France.

annotations.paragraph: Fighter jets
annotations.reason: Incomplete information lacking context or detail.

annotations.paragraph: At the end of July last year, Ukraine's President Zelensky said its air force had taken delivery of a batch of F-16 fighter jets from the West. He said many more were needed.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about the delivery of F-16 jets to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Nato countries, including Belgium, Denmark, the Netherlands and Norway, have pledged to give Ukraine 65 or more of the US-made planes, which they had been planning to retire from their air forces.
annotations.reason: Details the commitment of NATO countries to supply F-16 jets to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: In August 2023, the US gave permission for F-16s to be sent to Ukraine. Since then, Western nations have been training Ukrainian pilots to fly them.
annotations.reason: Explains the US's role in allowing F-16 transfers and training pilots.

annotations.paragraph: Phillips O'Brien, Professor of Strategic Studies at St Andrews University says: "Ukraine will be using the F-16s mostly for defence against air attacks."
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary on the intended use of F-16s by Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: The US-based Center for Strategic and International Studies says they could eventually be given extra roles, such as attacking Russian air defence systems, command centres and supply depots, and engaging Russian aircraft in Ukrainian airspace.
annotations.reason: Offers analysis on potential future roles of F-16s in Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Air defence systems
annotations.reason: The paragraph is a heading and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: To counter Russian drone and missile attacks on Ukraine's cities and infrastructure, Western nations have sent it several types of air defence system.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context about the purpose of the air defence systems being sent to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: These range from the UK's short-range anti-aircraft weapon, Starstreak, to the Patriot missile system.
annotations.reason: The paragraph lists specific types of air defence systems supplied to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: European nations have sent more than 200 German-made Leopard 1 and Leopard 2 tanks, according to figures from the Kiel Institute.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific information about the number and type of tanks sent to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: The US sent 31 of its M1 Abrams tanks, which are thought to be the most advanced in the world.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific information about the tanks sent by the US to Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Anti-tank weapons
annotations.reason: This is a section header, not a paragraph.

annotations.paragraph: Western countries first responded to Russia's invasion in February 2022 by supplying Ukraine with defensive weapons to counter the enemy's armoured brigades.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the initial response to the invasion.

annotations.paragraph: The US and UK supplied thousands of Javelin and Nlaw anti-tank missiles. These were considered crucial in stopping the advance of Russian forces on Kyiv.
annotations.reason: Details specific weapons supplied and their impact.

annotations.paragraph: Drones
annotations.reason: This is a section header, not a paragraph.

annotations.paragraph: Drones have been used extensively throughout the war, for surveillance, targeting, launching missiles and as "kamikaze" weapons.
annotations.reason: Describes the role and use of drones in the conflict.

annotations.paragraph: Turkey supplied missile-firing Bayraktar TB2 drones at the start of the conflict, the US has provided "Switchblade" kamikaze drones, and several countries have sent commercial surveillance drones, such as the Chinese-made DJI Mavic 3.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific information about the types of drones supplied by various countries to Ukraine, which is directly relevant to the article's focus on arms supply.
